pull.title: refactor: Return CAutoFile from BlockManager::Open*File()
pull.body: This is required for https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/28052, but makes sense on its own, because offloading logic to `CAutoFile` instead of re-implementing it allows to delete code and complexity.

verification.payload:
tree d34f7fbba3507483e03c6d120ab23c930c2ddbdb
parent f608a409f7591b4f5cf170898bee58b9d9dcf1b6
author MarcoFalke <*~=`'#}+{/-|&$^_@721217.xyz> 1688489989 +0200
committer MarcoFalke <*~=`'#}+{/-|&$^_@721217.xyz> 1694781231 +0200

refactor: Drop unused fclose() from BufferedFile

This was only explicitly used in the tests, where it can be replaced by
wrapping the original raw file pointer into a CAutoFile on creation and
then calling CAutoFile::fclose().

Also, it was used in LoadExternalBlockFile(), where it can also be
replaced by the (implicit call to the) CAutoFile destructor after
wrapping the original raw file pointer in a CAutoFile.

events.message:
refactor: Drop unused fclose() from BufferedFile

This was only explicitly used in the tests, where it can be replaced by
wrapping the original raw file pointer into a CAutoFile on creation and
then calling CAutoFile::fclose().

Also, it was used in LoadExternalBlockFile(), where it can also be
replaced by the (implicit call to the) CAutoFile destructor after
wrapping the original raw file pointer in a CAutoFile.

tree 3ded8f9c6e98d3ba651d6261851c20d5d7312c5c

committer MarcoFalke <*~=`'#}+{/-|&$^_@721217.xyz> 1694781257 +0200

Make BufferedFile to be a CAutoFile wrapper

This refactor allows to forward some calls to the underlying CAutoFile,
instead of re-implementing the logic in the buffered file.

events.body:
tACK fa56c421be

Clean refactor needed for future work.

comments.body: Nit: Would removing this in the second commit when the `FILE *` is changed to `CAutoFile` make more sense?
Nit: Include `cstdio` where this is used?
Now that `fclose` is removed, copies are allowed, because they no longer lead to a double-free undefined behavior segfault (Calling `fclose` twice on the same pointer)
